awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Developments in High Performance Electronic Structure Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on implementing newly developed numerical methods and software engineering approaches into widely used computer codes used in biology, chemistry, materials science and engineering, physics, chemical and mechanical engineering and many other science and engineering fields. GAMESS (General Atomic and Molecular Electronic Structure System) is the most broadly used highly scalable computational chemistry program with more than 100,000 users worldwide. NWChem is likewise a very popular computational chemistry code, as are MPQC (Massively Parallel Quantum Chemistry) and AIMS (Ab Initio Multiple Spawning).  All of these codes are distributed at no cost via the Web.  While these codes have all been developed by computational chemists, they impact a multitude of disciplines in science and engineering. 

The new software is highly scalable, thereby enabling the study of fundamentally critical problems, including the structure of liquids (water among them), the formation of atmosrpheric aerosols, heterogeneous catalysis, and photochemistry and photobiology. In addition, the new software is implemented so as to take advantage of new hardware such as the graphical processing units (GPU). Three of the principal investigators (Gordon, Martinez, Windus) are among the world leaders in such developments.

All of the new developments are to be incorporated into both graduate and undergraduate courses in both chemistry and computer science. In addition, downloadable modules are placed on an accessible web site.  The results of the research are to be reported at national meetings, such as those organized by the American Chemical Society, IEEE, and the Materials Research Society. Videos of these presentation are placed on the Web, so that researchers and educators who are unable to attend the meetings can access the results of this project. The Web site contains also a set of lessons learned to aid subsequent researchers.

This award pertains to the Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation (SI2) solicitation. Its funding sources include the Division of Chemistry (MPS/CHE), the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (OMA) of the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS), the Office of Cyberinfrastructure (OCI), the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation (ENG/CMMI), and the Division of Materials Research (MPS/DMR).

por.por_cntn:
This award led to the development of computer software for quantum mechanical modeling of physical and chemical phenomena with accuracy that cannot be achieved with current mainstream simulation tools. Highly accurate simulation of molecules is of fundamental importance to all of chemistry and materials science, and by extension to biology. Example of phenomena where high accuracy simulation is crucial include binding of medicines to proteins or nucleic acids in a human body; such binding is the key to the effectiveness of these medicines, yet it is rather weak and calls for extreme accuracy not yet possible with the current tools.


Highly accurate quantum mechanical simulation methods do exist, but unfortunately they require too much computer time and can only be applied to very small molecules (with one or two dozen atoms) that are rarely relevant to vital problems in materials science or biology. In the course of this project we developed algorithms and software that allow to dramatically reduce the cost of such accurate methods so that they can be applied confidently to systems with several hundred atoms! Such breakthrough is possible only by removing the fundamental bottlenecks of all accurate methods as well as by harnessing the power of modern parallel computers.


This award produced several major outcomes, primarily in the form of new features in existing popular software packages used by chemists (such as GAMESS and Orca) and in the form of new and/or improved software components. All software produced in this project is freely available to everyone and had already been adopted by many other researchers, thus boosting the broader impact of this project. First, several new simulation models were developed that describe particularly accurately the interactions of electrons in atoms and molecules when they are close (so-called explicitly correlated methods) and thus allow to achieve more reliable simulation results than possible otherwise. Second, accurate quantum mechanical methods were formulated such that they can applied to hundreds of atoms by taking advantage of locality of quantum interactions. Lastly, novel software components were developed that will allow accurate quantum mechanical simulations to harness the combined power of large supercomputers composed of hundreds of thousands of processing cores.
